parts:
Here’s a compact map of **recent (≈2023–2025) research directions around model categories**, with concrete pointers so you can judge current activity level.

### 1) Bridging model and ∞-worlds (especially **monoidal**)
A 2025 result shows the **homotopy theory of monoidal relative categories models monoidal (and symmetric monoidal) ∞-categories**, and as a payoff: *every presentably (symmetric) monoidal ∞-category admits a (symmetric) monoidal model presentation*. This tightens the bridge Lurie sketched and makes monoidal presentations a theorem of record, not folklore. citeturn0search0turn0search7

### 2) Making **Bousfield localizations** play well with algebra
There’s active work on **when localization preserves monoidal/operadic structures**—e.g., criteria ensuring the **monoid axiom** survives **enriched** left Bousfield localizations—together with updated expositions on how localizations generate stable model structures of spectra inside a given base. This matters any time you want derived algebra structures after localization. citeturn0search2turn0search5

### 3) Recognition and **presentation theorems** for whole homotopy theories
Fresh “recognition” results characterize when a given (enriched) model category is **Quillen-equivalent to a presheaf category** with the projective model structure. Parallel tracks refine **models of (∞,1)-categories** (via Segal/double categories) with explicit model structures and Quillen equivalences between the competing presentations. These give new, checkable entry points to build models for homotopy theories of interest. citeturn0search16turn1search3turn1search7

### 4) **Equivariant / parametrized** homotopy via model categories
On the equivariant side, there’s movement on structural tools (e.g., **norms** and recognition principles) and on how model structures support them; on the parametrized side, new frameworks for **parametrized ∞-categories** clarify how classical parametrized model categories present higher-categorical structures. Expect continued tightening of Quillen-level foundations behind equivariant and parametrized phenomena. citeturn0search18turn0search10turn0search20turn0search6

### 5) Model-categorical **foundations for derived analytic / condensed / bornological** geometry
Multiple strands push derived methods beyond algebraic geometry: foundations for **derived analytic geometry** via simplicial objects in exact categories; representability theorems in analytic settings; and **bornological/condensed** flavors where one still wants localizing invariants and stacky moduli with homotopy-theoretic control. These works typically implement model or dg-presentations to access ∞-categorical results. citeturn1search0turn1search8turn1search13turn1search9

### 6) New **monoidal model structures** for algebraic and enriched contexts
Recent constructions put **monoidal model structures** on categories that interact with dg- or internal algebra (e.g., curved coalgebras Quillen-equivalent to dg-cats, or module categories internal to a lextensive base), often with monoidal Quillen equivalences. This widens the catalogue of algebraic settings where homotopical algebra works “out of the box.” citeturn0search9turn0search11

### 7) Ongoing **motivic** refinements (built on model presentations)
Motivic homotopy continues to evolve: non-\(\mathbb A^1\)-invariant motivic spectra and structural results for the motivic sphere; strengthened **norms/transfers** packages. While modern expositions use stable ∞-categories, the standard motivic model structures remain the hands-on presentations many constructions pass through. citeturn1search6turn1search14turn1search10

### 8) **Stabilization technology** and spectra models
There’s sustained attention on how stabilization interacts with specific models (e.g., symmetric vs. sequential spectra and transferability of model structures), and on localization-based routes to stable structures for algebras/modules within a chosen ambient model category. This is practical know-how for building bespoke stable homotopy theories. citeturn1search18turn0search5

### 9) Fresh **model structures for algebraic gadgets**
Work continues on explicit model structures in algebraic contexts (e.g., **simplicial algebras via Dold–Kan**) that keep derived functors under tight, computable control—a recurring need in applied and geometric homotopy theory. citeturn1search16

### 10) Interfaces with **triangulated** representability
Although more triangulated than model-centric, there’s renewed activity on **Brown representability variants** under additional structure (graded actions, strong generation). These results often get *used* by passing to or from a model presentation of the same homotopy theory. citeturn0search1

---

#### Meta-trend (honest reading)
Much day-to-day homotopy theory is now phrased at the ∞-categorical level, but **model categories remain the preferred *presentations*** whenever you need transferred structures, explicit cofibration/fibration factorizations, or monoidal control. The newest results either (i) **prove that desired ∞-categorical gadgets admit clean model presentations** (notably in the monoidal case), or (ii) **sharpen the toolkit**—localization, recognition, enrichment—so those presentations can be built and used reliably. citeturn0search0turn0search2turn0search16

If you want, I can tailor this to your interests (e.g., motivic + tt-geometry, or operator-algebraic K-theory) and propose concrete, publication-sized projects with prerequisites and first computations.
